instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: Hi everyone! First post here. I am hoping someone can help me with an issue I'm having with a 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. I bought this computer from a guy who turned it on one morning and said he heard a little pop, then a little puff of smoke and a burning smell came out of it and it stopped working. I opened it up to find that a inductor had cracked in half, so I replaced it with the exact component from another board. It still doesn't boot up. I get 20v @ 2.76a. I have track pad click, the fans kick on after it gets hot and it will power USB device, but no image and no start up chime. With power disconnected it seems like most of the components above the CPU Near back of the MacBook are shorted to ground. Also voltages seem off from the schematics. At least in that area. I have attached an image with a circle around the component I have replace. Maybe the CPU is cooked?

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

I suppose you have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board there.
Remember to post corresponding board code, when start new thread.

The circled coil is L7600, for <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL>.

"seems like most of the components above the CPU Near back of the MacBook are shorted to ground"
CPU coils have low resistance to ground as normal.

Post L7210 voltage after 15s.
Also check for USB activity (not power).

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: Hi! Thanks for the reply. Sorry, yes it’s a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board. Not sure how to check for USB activity. When I plug a mouse in the beam lights up in the bottom, but what other ways might I check? I will post L7210 voltage after 15s. Tomorrow evening. Thanks again!

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
"Not sure how to check for USB activity"
Read here:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: Hi! ok, so Voltage on L7210 after 15s is 1.078 on pin 2 and 1.08.2 on pin 1. After plugging in a USB drive the light goes on and off a few times then stays on, just like when plugged into a working computer.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
The board is stuck, doesn't boot.
CPU core should drop to 0.6V aprox, when board really boots.

Overvoltage occured on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> rail and that might fried sensitive components.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: I'm thinking GPU is cooked on this board. Is that what you are saying also or can it be something else?

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: What components should I check at this point?

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
There is no dedicated GPU; just Intel iGPU, embedded into CPU.

Very strange to get L7600 broken and nothing else failed on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> power supply.
Do you get correct 5V at <CAPACITOR>C7607</CAPACITOR>?

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: Thanks for the reply! The reason I was wondering if it’s the embedded GPUis because I found a video where the same MacBook has pretty much the same symptoms and the guy tests using an oscilloscope and shows that the board can’t complete the start up process and gets stuck similar to this board. I also find it strange that nothing else seems to be broken, yet it won’t boot. I will get back to you about getting  5V at <CAPACITOR>C7607</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: Hi, sorry it's been a few days, but was super busy, now back to the fun stuff! :) ... Yes, in fact I get 5.16v at <CAPACITOR>C7607</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
Did you test the board alone on the desk?
No need to connect anything, apart of charger.
Just see if CPU core voltage drops from 1V to 0.6V after a while.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: Yes, I tested just the board on the desk. I will have to check the CPU core voltage again, but it was not going to 0.6v after a minute. It seemed to be staying at 1.08v.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
Shouldn't be the case, but try known good BIOS.
Don't forget to make backup of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> first.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: I will have to get myself a cheap programmer. Can you recommend one? As always, thanks for your help!

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
You can use even CH341 if you remove the SPI chip.
However, Medusa programmer, with dedicated adapter, can do the job onboard.
You can find other programmers and adapters on Internet...

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: I picked up a CH341A programer and was able to get a clean EFI BIOS written with my own serial numbers. It's back on the board and the voltage IS now going down after 10 -15 seconds, but it's going down to 0.544 volts and still no image. still 19.8v and 2.50a (after half hour or so it goes to 19.9v and around 1.77a) in the housing with everything, including the battery connected. After some time it gets very hot and the fans kick on. I'm stumped.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
CPU core looks like board is booting.
Did you check for USB activity and external video?

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: It does not appear to have any activity on a USB thumb drive with a light on it, nor does it show video on an external display.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
Same behavior on all ports?
Check if you get 5V at L3500 and LB700; depending where USB device is connected.

Just in case, do PRAM and SMC reset.

And test external video with J8500 disconnected.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
5.1v at L3500 and 36.3mv at LB700. I've done PRAM and SMC reset a few times, but no luck. 
After disconnecting J800 and having the external display connected on the usb-c  port, still no display. Two things that might also be worth mentioning. 1. I only have 3 of the 4 USB post working, as one had a bad pad under it and even after running a jumper, that port is not working at all when you plug anything into it. I was planning on reworking that if the board would be worth the effort, but wasn't sure if it needed to be working right now to at least get the board running. I thought if it was an issue I would not get 20v. Am I wrong there? ... 2. I only have  1.074v on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_SO_CPU</SIGNAL> rather than 1.5.  .. It also has an ohms reading of 3.0

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: Sorry, back where you asked me to post L7210 voltage after 15s. I had done that before reflashing the EFI BIOS and the readings were 1.078 on pin 2 and 1.08.2 on pin 1. Now that reading is 0.544v. <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is 1.074v

threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is at L7210.
No idea what you are doing there; can't help if you don't post accurate information.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message: Pin 1 of L7210 says 0.544v. What should I try next?

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Brain Dead.
threads.message:
If CPU core drops from 1V to 0.5V aprox, board should boot.
Unless CPU has an internal problem, which blocks it immediately after boot; maybe on iGPU side.
